captions.text:
your Lewisham fire report,
by the way.

It didnÂ’t work out
with Daniel Cleaver?

Look, are you and Cosmo
in this together?

I mean, you seem
to go out of your way...

to try to make me feel
like a complete idiot...

every time I see you,
and you really needn't bother.

I already feel like an idiot
most of the time anyway--

with or without
a fireman's pole.

I don't think
you're an idiot at all.

I mean, there are elements
of the ridiculous about you.

And you tend to let
whatever's in your head...

without much consideration
of the consequences.

I realize that when I met you
at the turkey curry buffet...

that I was unforgivably rude
and wearing a reindeer jumper...

that my mother had
given me the day before.

what I'm trying to say
very inarticulately is...

Ah. A part from the smoking
and the drinking...

and the vulgar mother
and the verbal diarrhea.

No. I like you very much--
just as you are.

title: Bridget Jones's Diary (7/12) Movie CLIP - Just As You Are (2001) HD

comments.text:
My Journey To The Ocean -  
http://www.amazon.com/Journey-Ocean-Colors-Rainbow-Book-ebook/dp/B00QI89NW4/ref=sr_1_1?tag=geolinker-20&ie=UTF8

Like Bridget Jones Diary, this book has all of the fuzzy, pink, glittery 
frills of the standard chick-lit novel- the feminine musing of superficial 
concerns, the goofball friends, the fairytale references, those wicked 
sabatuerettes of progress who bring out those ugly feelings of competition, 
the wrong Mr. Right, and the oh-so-right Mr. Wrong, and the general climate 
of "I wasn't looking for this, but I found it anyway" all play "by the 
book" that is the over arching methodology of this genre.

Though, this book has something more; beyond the fuzzy pinkness, is a 
recurring theme of expletives, the need to urinate at inconvenient times, 
drunken disorderlyness, more expletives, infidelity, and the "iron clad 
virgin" that is the protagonist which rather makes a mockery of resistance, 
while most chick lit novels skirt around the issue with holier-than-though 
subtexts. It could be its autobiographical nature, that avoids the vapidity 
of your average chick-lit novel, OR it could be the periodical 
philosophical introspection that interlude the story's progression, or it 
could be both? I think it is both.

I love this book, I enjoyed it immensely- all of the "characters" aroused a 
subtle reminder to find meaning in everyday life. AND...the moral of the 
story? Ironically is, "No one can save you, but yourself, and don't you 
forget it!" I love this book, I love it most of all because it doesn't 
expect women to just be satisfied with glittery, pinkness. Lena Mikado if 
you please, lead the rainbow parade of woman pride, into the turquoise 
waters so that we can all find our ocean!
http://www.amazon.com/Journey-Ocean-Colors-Rainbow-Book-ebook/dp/B00QI89NW4/ref=sr_1_1?tag=geolinker-20&ie=UTF8
﻿

comments.text:
She is much more adorable in this movie than the sequel. Her eyes are big, 
round and honest (not that she isn't honest in the sequel, but there was no 
featuring of her eyes as in this one), and her hair is simple but pretty. I 
wonder why they choose to portray her so negatively in the sequel. :-(

comments.author: Helen Back

comments.text:
If you follow the movie and pay close attention to Mark Darcy, it is 
evident that he has always loved Bridget since their childhood. He just 
didn't realize it until they kept bumping into each other at different 
occasions. When you watch the credits rolling at the end of the movie, 
check out how he held her hand with a very boyish crush on Bridget when he 
was 8 and she was 4....that's the sign. He even aluded to it when they were 
cooking together in the movie.﻿
